Dear Ms. Gordy:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• Be signed and dated.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. You must contest or agree to the
issuance of a provisional license in writing, on the CWL-4617 within 15 days, with
submission of the corrective action plan. If you do not submit the CWL-4617, it will be
treated as contested. Even if you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must
still submit an acceptable corrective action plan
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Medical, dental and mental health care
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12507
Section • (1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
Description living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental,
and mental health care provided must be documented in
the youth's record.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Alleged that agency failed to get a pregnant female to the hospital
when labor had started.
Investigation The acting Chief Administrator was notified in person on
08/21/24 that DCWL had opened an investigation regarding the
complaint.
All of the following interviews were conducted jointly with
DHHS Worker.
Youth A was interviewed face to face on 08/21/24. The
interview was conducted with a Spanish speaking translator.
Youth A is 17 year old youth who resides at Angel House in the
independent living program. Youth A reported she gave birth to
her infant at Angel House in the early morning hours of 08/19/24.
Youth A reported on 08/18/24, around 1:00 pm, she began having
contractions. Youth A reported she told a staff, whom she did not
know, that she had been having contractions. Youth A reported
she informed this staff of this around midnight in person on
08/18/24 before this staff ended her shift. There were no other
witnesses present during this time. Youth A reported this staff did
not say anything when she informed her of the contractions. Youth
A reported that at 6:30am on 08/19/24 she was having strong
contractions and asked Youth B to contact Staff 1. Youth A
reported Youth B was instructed by Staff 1 to call 911. Youth A
reported her water broke while EMS was on the way to Angel
House. Youth A reported Staff 2 arrived and took over the phone
call with EMS and then assisted her with the birth of her child.
Youth A reported the birth occurred just before EMS arrived.
Youth A reported Angel House staff never told her what to do if
she was in labor. Youth A denied that staff had told her they would
2

not be able to take her to the hospital if labor started because they
were short staffed.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face on 08/21/24. Staff 1
reported there is no staffing at the program from Midnight to
8:30am in the morning. Staff 1 is the Independent Living (IL)
caseworker for Youth A. Staff 1 reported at 8:44am on 08/19/24
she received a text and then a phone call from Youth B who
reported Youth A was in labor. Staff 1 reported she instructed
Youth B to call 911 while she called Staff 2 and directed her to go
to the agency right away. Shortly thereafter she found out Youth A
had delivered her baby and Staff 2 had assisted. Staff 1 reported
that Staff 2 had arrived promptly at 8:51am and EMS arrived at
8:56am. Staff 1 reported these times were documented by the
“Ring Doorbell” which begins recording when the door bell is rung.
Staff 1 was asked if a birth plan was discussed with Youth A, and
she said her doctor had informed her if contractions are 5 minutes
apart, she should go to the hospital. Staff 1 denied Youth A was
ever told that staff could not take her to the hospital, but that staff
would call 911 if she was in active labor.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face on 08/21/24. Staff 2
reported on 08/19/24 between 8:40am and 8:45am she received a
phone call from Staff 1 requesting for her to go to Angel House as
quickly as she could as Youth A was reported to be in labor. Staff
2 reported she arrived to the agency at about 8:55am as she had
been just a few blocks away. Staff 2 reported she took the phone
from Youth B and finished the call with EMS. Staff 2 then assisted
with the delivery of the baby as it was crowning. Staff 2 reported
the delivery occurred and EMS arrived at 8:56am. Staff 2 was
asked if there was a birth plan for Youth A and she said she was
not sure, but Youth A had been told to let staff know if she was
having contractions and if staff were not at the agency, she should
call 911.
Staff 2 was asked if there were any indications that Youth A was
having contractions on 08/18/24. Staff 2 reported that Staff 4, who
was working from 3pm to 11pm on that day called her at 8:04pm
to inform her that Youth A had told her she had contractions
around 9:00am on this day and Staff 2 and Staff 4 thought it might
be “Braxton-Hicks”. Staff 2 reported they communicate with Youth
A using Google translate since Youth A does not speak English.
The acting Chief Administrator was interviewed in person on
08/21/24. The Chief Administrator reported she learned of the
3

birth of Youth A’s baby at 10:23am on 08/19/24. The Chief
Administrator reiterated the events as reported by Staff 1 and Staff
2. The Chief Administrator reported she was not aware of a birth
plan for Youth A.
Youth B was interviewed in person via a translator face to
face on 08/21/24. Youth B reported Youth A had informed her on
08/18/24 that she had some pain in the afternoon and around
9:00pm, Youth B had told staff about it. Youth B was unsure who
the staff was as she was a new staff. Youth B reported she had
told this staff that Youth A’s pain was coming and going and then
staff responded “okay” and she does not believe the staff checked
on Youth A. Youth B reported the next morning Youth A texted her
at 4:27am saying she could not take the pain anymore. Youth B
reported she and Youth A discussed what they should do, and
Youth B reported “what can we do because that lady is not going
to do anything”. Youth B reported Youth A then called her at
8:02am saying she could not take the pain, and she went to Youth
A’s bedroom and soon after called Staff 1. Youth B reported Staff
1 then told her to call 911. Youth B reported she was trying to
explain to EMS but the language barrier was making it difficult.
Youth B reported Staff 2 then arrived and took over the call with
EMS.
Youth B was asked if staff had ever checked on Youth A after she
told staff on 08/18/24 that Youth A was reporting pain. Youth B
reported Youth A had told her that staff had not checked on her.
Youth B was asked if she had ever been told by staff what to do if
someone is in active labor and she stated she did not know.
Staff 3 was interviewed briefly via telephone on 08/26/24. Staff
3 is the supervisor of Staff 1. Staff 3 was asked if she knew of a
birth plan for Youth A. Staff 3 reported that she was unaware of a
birthing plan. Staff 3 was not present while Youth A went into
labor.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on 08/26/24. Staff 4
reported she is the Child Welfare Associate Coordinator for the
agency foster care program and helps out once in a while at Angel
House. Staff 4 reported she was working the 2:30pm to 11:00pm
shift at Angel House on 08/18/24 and she was the only staff
member present during this time. Staff 4 reported around 8:00pm
on 08/18/24, Youth A had informed her she had pain around
9:00am that day. Staff 4 did not report asking any clarifying
questions. Staff 4 reported that at the time Youth A informed her
of this she looked fine and Youth A did not exhibit pain or distress.
4

When Staff 4 left her shift at 11:00pm, she did not check on Youth
A. Staff 4 reported when her shift was over and she was about to
leave for the day, Youth A and Youth B were downstairs in the
kitchen and Youth A looked fine. Youth A and Youth B had been
downstairs when she left her shift and there was no indication that
Youth A was in distress. Staff 4 reported Youth A looked fine. Staff
4 denied Youth B had told her that Youth A was in pain during the
afternoon. Staff 4 was asked if she knew of a birthing plan for
Youth A and she reported that if contractions are 5 minutes apart
EMS was to be called. Staff 4 reported Youth A never reported
she had pain in the evening of 08/18/24.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
• Case File: The case file was reviewed and did not contain
a specific birth plan or safety plan for Youth A. Youth A was
placed with the agency on 6-12-24. She was 37 weeks
pregnant when she went into labor.
• Email document. A policy/procedure document listed “24/7
On Call Services”, “Medical and Mental Services” and
“Pregnant/Parenting Only” services was reviewed.
• A time log for Staff 4’s shift on 8/18/2024.
The DHHS Worker did not have findings.
Analysis Youth A reported she was having contractions on the afternoon of
08/18/24 and told a staff person (Staff 4) of the contractions
around midnight and the staff did not respond. Youth A reported
Angel House staff had never told her what to do if she was in
labor.
Youth B reported on 08/18/24 around 9:00 pm she told a staff
(Staff 4) Youth A’s pain was coming and going and the staff
responded okay.
Staff 4 reported on 08/18/24, Youth A told her in the evening she
had pain in the morning of that day. Staff 4 denied Youth B had
informed her Youth A’s pain was coming and going. Staff 4
reported Youth A looked fine and did not exhibit any distress
during the evening hours and when she had completed her shift.
Staff 1 reported she instructed Youth B to call 911 on the morning
of 08/19/24. Youth B has limited knowledge of the English
language and should not have been directed to call 911.
Monitoring of Youth A’s medical needs was not conducted during
the day and evening of 08/18/24 and early morning hours of
08/19/24 given the reports of Youth A and Youth B. For Youth A
5

and Youth B the language barrier is significant which would
necessitate additional staff attention, and a plan initiated for Youth
A once contractions were reported.
Conclusion Violation Established.
Rule Code Policy and procedures
Title
Rule Code & Rule 400.12503. (1) An agency shall have and follow written
Section policies and procedures for the independent living services
Description provided.
(2) The policies and procedures must cover at least all the
following areas:
(i) Medical, dental, and mental health care.
ADDITIONAL The agency lacks a policy/procedure for a birth/safety plan for
FINDING: pregnant youth.
Investigation Staff 1, 2, 3, and 4 reported they were not aware of a specific birth
plan for Youth A.
The Chief Administrator reported she was not aware of a birth
plan for Youth A.
Youth A and B reported they were not aware of a birth plan.
Documents Reviewed:
• Email document. A policy/procedure document listed “24/7
On Call Services”, “Medical and Mental Services” and
“Pregnant/Parenting Only” services was reviewed.
o Agency policy does not specifically address a
procedure for a birth plan for pregnant youth.
Analysis The Chief Administrator and Staff 1, 2, 3, and 4 were not aware of
a birth plan for Youth A. Youth A and B reported not being aware
of a birth plan. A specific birth/safety plan should have been
developed specific to Youth A and in particular given her language
barrier.
Conclusion Violation Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the license be modified to a First Provisional license.
